title: Elizabeth Hurley reveals her late grandmother kept her breast cancer diagnosis a secret
text:
Elizabeth Hurley has revealed her late grandmother kept her breast cancer diagnosis a secret from her family as she raised awareness of the disease on Monday's This Morning.

The actress, 54, detailed losing her nan during a time 'when nobody spoke about it' back in 1992, and has since played a significant role in the fight against cancer for almost three decades.

Model Liz bravely told hosts Holly Willoughby and Phillip Schofield: 'I’ve been working to raise awareness for breast cancer for 25 years. I lost my grandmother to breast cancer. At that time, nobody spoke about breast cancer.'

Brave: Elizabeth Hurley has revealed her late grandmother kept her breast cancer diagnosis a secret from her family as she raised awareness of the disease on Monday's This Morning

The Austin Powers star previously revealed her relative showed her scars from a double mastectomy once she finally told her family about her diagnosis, but would often change the subject.

Reflecting on when breast cancer was a taboo subject, the Royals actress explained: 'When I started working for the breast cancer campaign, my grandmother had just died.

'When I was told it was started because women were dying, it really rang home for me, because she didn’t talk about it. There was no awareness, no pink ribbon campaign.'

Helping out: The actress, 54, has since played a significant role in the fight against cancer for almost three decades (pictured Estee Lauder's Breast Cancer Campaign event last week)

'There was no awareness, no pink ribbon campaign': The Austin Powers star detailed losing her nan during a time 'when nobody spoke about it' back in 1992

During her work as a global ambassador for the Estee Lauder Companies' Breast Cancer Awareness Campaign, Liz has insisted she's witnessed 'great changes' in research and attitudes towards the disease.

The media personality urged: 'People aren’t checking their own breasts. If you’re too young to have a mammogram, which is under 50 or in some countries under 40, you have to check your breasts. We’re raising awareness but we’re raising funds too.

One in eight women will develop breast cancer at some point in their life. However, those who have already had the disease have double the risk of developing a new cancer in another area of the same breast, or in the other breast.

Secret: The Austin Powers star previously revealed her relative showed her scars from a double mastectomy once she finally told her family about her diagnosis

Moving forward: The Royals actress has insisted she's witnessed 'great changes' in research and attitudes towards the disease

Genetics are thought to be the reason - but in the majority of cases, the exact genes responsible have not yet been discovered.

Last week, the film star took to Instagram to share a poignant message about the disease.

She penned on her platform: 'Every 15 seconds, somewhere in the world, a woman is diagnosed with breast cancer. In one way or another, we’re all drawn together by this disease.

'Grab your favourite pink lipstick and help us fund life-saving research. Draw a pink ribbon on your hand, post a photo, and share why it’s #TimeToEndBreastCancer.'

In good company: The media personality was joined by breast cancer survivor Lauren Mahon during her TV appearance

Standing out: Liz caught the eye in a sparkly red and fuschia pink midi dress, teamed with a pair of classic pointed heels

Elizabeth also encouraged fans to add #ELCDonates to their posts, as for each one Estée Lauder would donate $25 to The Breast Cancer Research Foundation.

The global campaign aims to both raise awareness of breast cancer and inspire people to take action, through donating to fund research.

Speaking about her involvement in the campaign, the mother-of-one explained: 'Every time someone shares with me that they got a mammogram because they heard our messages, or unfortunately tells me that they have been diagnosed with breast cancer, I’m reminded of why we must continue Evelyn’s [H. Lauder] mission.

'I’ve seen research we are funding in action, spoken to many leaders in the field and know how hopeful they all remain – we are making real progress towards a cure and must continue to fund that advancement!'

'Help us find life-saving research': Last week, the film star took to Instagram to share a poignant message about the disease
